title: The letter X: do we really need it?
content:
I’ve noticed that the letter X is employed in such a redundant manner these days. We already have K and S for that sound, so who really needs X?

Should I include X in my fonts or should I leave that one out?

I think, I think so.

 [‹ fontlab question contours don't close/connect](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201135657/http:/www.typophile.com/node/49980 "Go to previous forum topic") [Typophile: Do we need it? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201135657/http:/www.typophile.com/node/49795 "Go to next forum topic")
author: James Arboghast

comments.content: this joke is wearing thin

Like I said in [this other post](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201135657/http:/typophile.com/node/49788), about 15 years ago, I created for myself a phonetic alphabet in which all unnecessary or redundant characters were either omitted or re-assigned new sounds. I used the x to precede long vowels and did away with the silent e and all other letter formulas we use in the English language to indicate long vowel sounds. And I created a brand new letter to indicate the long bowel sound.

The alphabet was first called Planetease, and then I changed it to Earthish. I even matched it up to <cite>Twinkle Twinkle</cite> (that’s <cite>Sparkling Stella</cite> for the music snobs), like the real alphabet song. I showed it to my mom and she could actually read it without instruction. I thought I was a genius for a little while and it was a neat way to journal but then I quit using it.

It doesn’t just have a phonetic role:
